Text Narration:
Sonia Sotomayor shares some of her family photos with NPR. And the story of a little girl from the Bronx, who made it all the way to the Supreme Court. 

Her life began in the tenements of the Bronx -- in a community of Puerto Rican immigrants.

Audio Transcript: This was the 1950s. You didn't leave your house in my mother's generation without your hair made up and makeup on.
There was a sense of pride in how you look. My family's standard of living was no different than the entire neighborhood.
I can't tell you how people afforded it. When I first moved to the projects, you did not walk into an apartment that wasn't clean and decent looking.

Book Quote: "A tight few blocks in the South Bronx bounded the lives of my extended family: my grandmother matriarch of the tribe, her second husband, Gallego, her daughers and sons."

Text Narration:
Sotomayor excelled at Princeton, and would go off to Yale Law School and the New York District Attorney's office, before becoming a judge.

But, she recalls, her two worlds would sometimes collide.

Book Quote: "I could be yanked for a time into one world or the other, but mostly now I would be living suspended between the two."
Audio Transcript: I was never given permission to walk out on the streets by myself shopping. That wasn't true for Nelson. He was a boy and he was let out on the streets very early.
And at that time the South Bronx was Fort Apache -- the most crime ridden area in the nation, and he fell victim to drugs.
It's the scourge of many a poor neighborhood. And he was my dearest friend growing up. He took one road, I took another. And he died.
